Standard_Text: Project development team affirms compliance with all applicable accessibility and safety codes.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team selects a universal design development coordinator responsible for managing the design process and preparing the necessary materials to support certification.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team includes diverse stakeholders (e.g. employees of different job titles, men and women, various age groups, people with disabilities, potential visitors, representatives from client organization, representatives from design team, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team consults with universal design specialists.
Phases: InitiateSchematic DesignDesign DevelopmentSpecificationsOperations
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team conducts research with future facility users to identify and prioritize issues (e.g. confidential survey, design workshop, focus group, open meeting, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team conducts research on best practices in universal design, with particular attention to examples that demonstrate integration with other human centered design goals (e.g. sustainability, active living, environmental health, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Project development team develops marketing strategy to educate the public on the benefits of universal design.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Workshops occur at relevant stages of design and construction (e.g. initiate, schematic design, design development, construction documents, etc.).
Phases: InitiateSchematic DesignDesign DevelopmentSpecificationsOperations

Standard_Text: Expert in the field develops a universal design training program for designers and key stakeholders.
Designers and key stakeholders have access to universal design education materials.
Phases: InitiateSchematic DesignDesign DevelopmentSpecificationsOperations

Standard_Text: Clear floor spaces are at least 34 inches wide and 56 inches deep.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 3      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 3

Standard_Text: Clear floor spaces are at least 32 inches wide and 54 inches deep.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 3      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 3

Standard_Text: Clear floor spaces used for circulation are 6 inches wider than a stationary clear floor space, except at doors.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 3      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 3

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 90-degree turns are at least 43 inches wide entering and exiting the turn.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 90-degree turns are at least 39 inches wide entering and exiting the turn.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 90-degree turns have different widths entering and exiting the turn, such that neither is less than 36 inches and the sum of the width entering and exiting is 78 inches.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 180-degree turns are at least 72 inches in diameter.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 180-degree turns are at least 67 inches in diameter.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 180-degree turns utilize a T-shaped turning space, with the two arms of the T at least 16 inches long at a width of at least 40 inches, and the leg of the T at least 24 inches long at a width of at least 40 inches.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Turning spaces for 360-degree turns are provided in selected areas (e.g. selected work stations, sleeping rooms, etc.) that are at least 94 inches in diameter.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Knee clearance height is at least 29 inches, at selected features and elements (e.g. work stations, tables, drinking fountains, lavatories, etc.)
Knee clearance depth is at least 11 inches, as measured at the top of the knee clearance.
Knee clearance depth is at least 13 inches, as measured at the top of the toe clearance.
Toe clearance height is at least 13 inches.
Toe clearance height is at least 11 inches.
The maximum toe clearance depth counted as part of a clear floor space is 4 inches beyond the knee clearance depth, as measured at the top of the toe clearance.
Reach targets are not under or behind built elements or furniture.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Reach targets have a clear floor space positioned for side approach wherever knee or toe clearance is not provided.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Reach targets with only a forward approach overlap the clear floor space by at least 4 inches (i.e. knee and/or toe clearance brings reach target closer to user).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Reach targets are at least 12 inches from any corner.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Selected reach targets have overlapping clear floor spaces allowing right and left shoulder alignment for side and/or forward reach.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Selected reach targets that have a clear floor space for side approach positioned 10 inches or more from the reach target are 24-48 inches above the finished floor.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Selected reach targets that have a clear floor space for side approach positioned more than 10 inches of the reach target are 28-44 inches above the finished floor.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Selected reach targets have a clear floor space for side approach positioned 20 inches or less from the reach target.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 8      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 8

Standard_Text: Facility has circulation spaces that adhere to recognizable organizational concepts (e.g. linear, radial, grid, axial, central atrium, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Facility has similar plans for most floors and/or similar locations for toilet rooms, drinking water fountains, elevator lobbies, and emergency exits on each floor.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system provides access to areas of primary function without passing through other spaces and without unnecessary travel to remote areas.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system differentiates primary routes, zones, or nodes using variations in flooring, lighting, color, ceiling height, and/or other architectural features.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system assists in orientation and navigation by providing periodic views to the outside along primary routes.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system uses a consistent graphic strategy to identify and differentiate routes, rooms, and spaces.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system includes tactile guide strips on primary routes that have a different color and texture than the surrounding floor and detectable warnings.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system includes visual and tactile and/or audible directional signs, maps, or models at all primary entrances, the primary access point to each floor, and/or corridor intersections.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Wayfinding system includes systematic numbering of rooms.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 9      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 9

Standard_Text: Signs are readable from the expected viewing distance and not obstructed by objects.
Signs do not produce direct glare and are protected from reflected glare.
Signs provide all information in visual and tactile and/or audible format, including room purpose wherever signs provide room numbers.
Signs with an audio component have a headphone jack and volume control.
Selected signs use pictograms and/or more than one language.
A directory lists building occupants and room numbers under an organizational heading (e.g. company, department, specialty, etc.).
Signs at intersecting routes are perpendicular to the direction of travel from all approaches to the intersection.
Signs at intersecting routes provide navigation information (e.g. arrows guiding to range of room numbers, organizational headings, areas of primary function, etc.).
Selected signs link to additional online resources (e.g. QR Code).
Smart signs are provided on the premises (e.g. signs with radio frequency identifiers, near field communication, or other technology that allows communication with a personal computing device).
Signs located in dark areas or outdoors are backlit, reflective, and/or directly illuminated.
The width of primary routes are wide enough to allow an ambulatory person to pass a person using a wheeled mobility device.
Stairs, ramps, or escalators have an adjacent elevator or inclined moving walkway.
Goals: Body FitComfortPersonalizationSocial Integration

Standard_Text: Circulation spaces are smooth and slip resistant.
Transparent walls or doors along circulation spaces have a railing or other visual indicator to alert people to its presence.
Circulation spaces do not have floors or walls with visual patterns that distort perception.
Circulation spaces have seats with an adjacent clear floor space where primary routes intersect.
Architectural features distinguish primary entrances and exits from other entrances and exits (e.g. prominent signs, graphics, architectural features, landmarks, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Unique lighting and acoustic treatments highlight primary entrances and exits.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Primary entrances and exits are visible along the primary approach route of motor vehicles, pedestrians, and bicyclists.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Primary entrances and exits are available on all sides of the building abutting visitor parking areas and public streets.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Primary entrances and exits are protected against the direction of prevailing wind (e.g. screen walls, vestibules, air curtains, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Primary entrances and exits do not have steps or raised thresholds.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: All entrances and exits do not have steps or raised thresholds (including employee, service, and delivery entrances).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: All entrances are part of an accessible means of emergency egress.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Entrances are positioned to protect against water infiltration (e.g. covered, sloped at 1:48 max., drainage, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: The interior side of entrances have a means to  absorb, dry, or wick away water trafficked in by building users.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

Standard_Text: Primary entrances have an adjacent secure coat/bag check area.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 5 of 11      |      1 Credit: Implement 4 of 11

H2_Sec_Title: Emergency Exits and Areas of Rescue Assistance
Standard_Text: An accessible emergency exit or area of rescue assistance is adjacent to every access point to every floor.

H2_Sec_Title: Emergency Exits and Areas of Rescue Assistance
Standard_Text: Emergency exits and areas of rescue assistance are identified by floor-level illumination that guides building users to their location.

H2_Sec_Title: Emergency Exits and Areas of Rescue Assistance
Standard_Text: Emergency exits and areas of rescue assistance are identified by floor-level illuminated signs.

H2_Sec_Title: Emergency Exits and Areas of Rescue Assistance
Standard_Text: Emergency exits and areas of rescue assistance have tactile guide strips leading to their location.

H2_Sec_Title: Emergency Exits and Areas of Rescue Assistance
Standard_Text: Emergency exits and areas of rescue assistance are identified by audible beacons distinct from the fire alarm signal.
All doors intended for human passage are at least as wide as one clear floor space.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: All interior doors do not have steps or raised thresholds.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors on primary routes open and close automatically based on presence sensor.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors on primary routes open and close automatically when activated by pressing a button.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors that open and close automatically are wide enough to allow an ambulatory person to pass a person using a wheeled mobility device.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors that open and close automatically have sensors that hold open the door if the passageway is obstructed.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors that open and close automatically and/or have electronic locking mechanisms have an emergency power supply.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors are not required to access selected rooms and spaces (e.g., maze entry, air curtain, door with magnetic hold-open device).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors on primary routes have an adjacent area outside the door swing and circulation space to allow pausing or waiting.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors are located where they can be used without disrupting ongoing activities in the room or space.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors exiting a vestibule have the same overall passage width as those entering the vestibule.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors and/or door frames visually contrast with the surrounding walls.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors that swing into a circulation space are glazed or have a full-height view panel.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors in pairs are designated for entering and exiting, and labeled accordingly on both sides.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors on primary routes have hardware with design cues indicating the appropriate pushing or pulling action to open (e.g. plate or bar for pushing, U-shaped handle for pulling).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Selected doors can be secured and unsecured using magnetic swipe cards, electronic key fobs, smart phones, numeric keypads, or other technology in lieu of keys.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Doors that require hands to secure and operate have a shelf on both sides of the door.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Selected doors have an audio-video intercom system and/or two peoples, one at standing eye level, and the other at sitting eye level.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 18

Standard_Text: Stairway edges have photoluminescent stripe and/or color that contrasts with stair treads.
Interior stairways have equal riser heights of 6-7 inches and equal tread depths of 11-12 inches.
Exterior stairways and stairways in public assembly areas have equal riser heights of 4-7 inches and equal tread depths of 12-24 inches.
Stairways have no fewer than 3 and no greater than 10 risers for each run.
Stairways wider than 78 inches have at least one intermediate handrail.
Stairways with landings have resting areas outside the circulation space.
Stairways have a tactile walking surface indicator at the top of every run.
Stairways have added features to promote use in lieu of elevator (e.g. windows, bright light, vibrant color, music, doors held open magnetically, etc.).
Stairwells have glazing providing line of sight into and out of the stairwell.
Stairwells intended only for emergency egress are labeled accordingly.
Ramps are as wide as the general circulation space and/or run in the same direction of the general circulation space.
Ramp slope increases proportionally from a minimum slope of 1:12 to a minimum slope of 1:16, as the ramp length increases from 0 to 30 feet, measured horizontally.
Ramps with landings have resting areas outside the circulation space.
Handrails on stairways and ramps are provided at more than one height (e.g. one for adults and one for children).
Handrails on stairways and ramps are highlighted by luminescent striping or integrated lighting.
Handrails on stairways and ramps have tactile cues to indicate an upcoming landing.
All elevators have sufficient space for all people to enter, operate controls, and exit, without necessarily turning around.
Elevators have doors on both ends, allowing users to pass through without needing to turn around inside.
Elevators have sufficient space for people who use a wheeled mobility device to complete a 180-degree turn.
Elevators with security access controls (e.g. swipe card, key fob, biometrics, etc.) allow floor selection before and after authorization, and provide clear feedback when access is not authorized.
Elevators have an adjacent waiting area at all discharge levels that does not conflict with the circulation space.
Elevators are monitored by an employee who can provide assistance if needed.
Escalators have audible warnings prior to the beginning and end of trip.
Escalators have a tactile walking surface indicator upon approach.
Moving Walkways have a slope not exceeding 1:20.
Moving Walkways accommodate people who use wheeled mobility devices, strollers, rolling luggage, and shopping carts.
Moving Walkways have audible warnings prior to the beginning and end of trip.
Moving Walkways have a tactile walking surface indicator upon approach.
Electric lighting is even, free from glare, and does not cast distracting shadows.
Electric lighting is dimmed based on available daylight available.
Illumination levels can be adjusted in task areas (such as work stations, dining tables, bedside, etc.).
Illumination level changes occur gradually between spaces.
Illumination levels are sufficient based on occupancy and use.
Electric lighting in areas of primary function, work spaces, and toilet and bathing rooms have a color rendering index of 90 or higher.
Electric lighting systems are commissioned as per ASHRAE guide.
Electric lighting controls are within reach.
Selected electric lighting controls are labeled to indicate zone controlled.
Switch plates contrast in color from the surrounding wall.
Electric lighting controls can be activated by a remote control or voice command.
Electric lighting is on an occupancy sensor with an override switch.
Electric lighting controls have a master switch to control all lighting.
Daylight is available in all rooms and spaces.
Daylight levels are managed.
Phases: Schematic DesignDesign DevelopmentSpecificationsOperations

Standard_Text: Shading devices allow occupants to control daylight levels.
Shading devices reposition automatically based on the time of day and/or year.
Windows provide views for people of all heights.
Daylighting systems are commissioned as per ASHRAE guide.
Acoustic design features are compatible with the requirements of the space.
Acoustic design incorporates assistive listening systems.
Noise and vibration from building systems is controlled.
The volume of background music and other entertainment systems controllable.
Doors and windows are designed to the appropriate sound transmission class (STC).
Walls are designed to the appropriate sound transmission class (STC).
Acoustic design is commissioned as per ASHRAE guide.
Thermal comfort systems provide constant and uniform temperatures within a zone.
Thermal comfort systems are zoned to allow personal control of spaces.
Thermal comfort systems eliminate drafts through controlling air flow and wall and window insulation.
Thermal comfort systems are supplemented by ceiling or personal fans with multiple speed settings and occupancy sensors.
Thermal comfort systems incorporate personal environmental modules at individual task areas.
Thermal comfort systems are commissioned as per ASHRAE guide.
Public thermal comfort system controls are within reach.
Operable windows are provided with controls within reach.
Goals: Body FitUnderstandingWellnessComfortPersonalization

Standard_Text: Thermal comfort system can be programmed for different settings based on time of day and season.
Public thermal comfort system controls follow a common conceptual model.
Public thermal comfort system can be adjusted by remote control.
Indoor air quality system is designed based on a detailed occupant needs assessment.
Air contamination sources are reduced by achieving objectives 2-5 in ASHRAE guide.
Air contamination pathways are reduced by achieving objectives 6-8 in ASHRAE guide.
Indoor air quality systems are commissioned as per ASHRAE guide.
Selected site access points are identified by a landmark or prominent sign indicating facility name and/or street address.
Site access points are visible from all vehicular, pedestrian, and bicycle approach routes.
Site access points using a visual landmark have a tactile and/or audible cue.
Site access points with different functions use graphics to distinguish each access point (e.g. visitor entrance, employee entrance, ambulance entrance, etc.)
Site access points have maps, models, and/or directional signs indicating the location of primary destinations.
The site has separate vehicular, pedestrian, and bicycle routes.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has lines of sight from building entrances to public transportation stops, parking areas, and nearby roads.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has direct pedestrian access from all pedestrian site access points to a primary building entrance that does not cross vehicular ways or parking lots.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site pedestrian circulation network is integrated with local pedestrian routes.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has a traffic and parking load compatible with the local traffic and parking infrastructure.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site does not have any stairways or ramps between any site access points and primary destinations, nor between any parking lots and primary destinations.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site utilizes indoor circulation spaces including elevators and ramps to overcome topography too steep for an exterior accessible route.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has direct routes between entrances of neighboring buildings.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has indoor connections between most buildings.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site design protects selected outdoor gathering spaces from sun, wind, and/or inclement weather.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has recreation trails with a solid surface suitable for outdoor walking, running, skating, and/or cycling that are connected to the general circulation network.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: The site has a raised garden for growing food or vegetation maintained by building users.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 7 of 12      |      2 Credits: Implement 6 of 12      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 12

Standard_Text: All pedestrian routes are wide enough for an ambulatory person to pass a wheeled mobility device user.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Primary pedestrian routes are wide enough to allow a person using a wheeled mobility device to complete a 180-degree turn anywhere along the route.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Pedestrian routes shared with bicycles and/or vehicles use traffic calming devices, are marked as shared, and/or are marked to designate lanes for each type of transportation.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Pedestrian routes adjacent to vehicular ways and passenger loading zones are marked by distinct paving materials and curb or protective edges such as bollards, chains, walls, and/or planted areas.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Pedestrian routes are continuous throughout the site.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Primary pedestrian routes have protection from the sun, wind, and/or inclement weather.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Primary pedestrian routes have electronic guidance systems (e.g. wayfinding app, talking signs) or tactile guide strips leading to primary destinations.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Street crossings do not have curbs within the marked crossing area (preferred) or have curb ramps as wide as the marked crossing area.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings are perpendicular to the vehicular way.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings denote safe crossing boundaries with visual markings.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings denote safe crossing boundaries with tactile markings.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings have detectable warnings with a color and texture that is different from tactile guide strips and detectable warnings at transit stop platform edges.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings at signaled intersections have pedestrian crossing signals with visual countdown displays and audible beacons.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings have cycle times appropriate for slow moving pedestrians.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings reduce crossing distance using curb extensions (bulb outs) at corners.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings on streets with more than two through-traffic lanes (for automobiles) have refuge islands.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Street crossings have electric lighting.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 6 of 10      |      1 Credit: Implement 5 of 10

Standard_Text: Bicycle routes are provided and form a continuous network throughout the site.
Bicycle routes connect to the general circulation network.
Bicycle routes are wide enough to allow, or have designated lanes for traffic in opposing directions and/or a lane for pedestrians.
Transit stops have signs indicating routes served.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops provide information for orientation and/or navigation (e.g. route maps, schedules, local area maps, directories, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops have electric lighting.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops are located close to a primary entrance.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit platform edges have barriers with doors along the platform edges that automatically open aligned with transit vehicle doors.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit platform edges have detectable warnings that are a different color and texture from tactile guide strips and detectable warnings at pedestrian street crossings.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Selected transit stops have a shelter protecting from sun, wind, and/or inclement weather with sufficient space for people to enter, exit, and wait, including wheelchair users, people with luggage, strollers, and shopping carts.
Goals: ComfortBody FitWellnessCultural Appropriateness
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops with a shelter use active climate control measures.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: All transit stops have seating, and if a shelter exists, the seating is both inside and outside the shelter.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops provide direct view of oncoming transit vehicles and at least a 270-degree field of vision, even if within a shelter.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops have a leaning bar.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Transit stops are marked to discourage illegal parking.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Selected transit stops provide public wireless internet access.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have a continuous network of pedestrian routes with marked crossings wherever the pedestrian route crosses a vehicular way.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have electric lighting.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking capacity is based on a study of needs that accounts for any on-street parking and considers sharing strategies with any adjacent buildings and facilities.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities include spaces for alternate transportation (e.g. bicycles, scooters, or motorcycles) are provided.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities for automobiles, bicycles, and/or other forms of alternative transportation have selected areas of covered parking for each form of transportation.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have the spaces nearest to the building entrances reserved for specified priority parking classes.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have marked spaces that are regularly re-striped to prevent fading.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have space to store snow that does not conflict with any circulation space or priority parking space.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities are divided into zones uniquely coded with numbers, letters, colors, or symbols.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have variable message signs indicating location of available spaces, including accessible spaces, and/or such information is available on a mobile device (e.g. phone application, phone-friendly website, etc.)
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have intelligent parking systems that automatically adjust the number of priority spaces to meet demand.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking facilities have charging stations for electric vehicles.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: All accessible parking spaces are also van accessible.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 7 of 13      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 13

Standard_Text: Parking payment systems have payment transaction machines located on pedestrian routes entering/exiting the parking facility that permit payment prior to returning to vehicle.
Parking payment systems do not require returning to vehicle after paying.
Parking payment systems allow online payment.
Parking payment systems accept credit cards or smart cards in addition to cash/coin.
Parking payment systems have a button to call for staff assistance.
Parking payment systems prominently display current prices before entering parking facility and at payment transaction machines.
Parking payment systems allow users to change their mind after entering facility without cost.
Passenger loading and waiting areas do not obstruct pedestrian routes, crosswalks, vehicular lanes, bus loading zones, or bicycle lanes.
Passenger loading and waiting areas are provided at primary entrances and are marked accordingly.
Passenger loading and waiting areas have protection from the sun, wind, and/or inclement weather.
Where security limits vehicle idling at passenger loading and waiting areas, (e.g. airports, etc.), a remote waiting area is also provided (e.g. mobile phone lot).
Passenger loading and waiting areas are visible from remote waiting areas (e.g. airport mobile phone lot).
Spaces with similar functions and noise requirements are grouped together.
Indoor spaces are located adjacent to outdoor spaces with similar functions.
Flexible spaces that can be adapted to various functional requirements are provided.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Fixtures, equipment, and waste receptacles do not cause pinch points in circulation space.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms are organized by the order in which fixtures, equipment, and waste receptacles are used.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have space for a waiting queue that does not conflict with circulation spaces.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have a full-height mirror that is visible to people before they exit the restroom.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have personal hygiene supplies or dispensers.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have a changing table with an adjacent lavatory, diaper receptacle, and supplies (e.g. hand sanitizer, baby wipes, baby powder, diapers).

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have ventilation systems activated by a presence sensor.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have hypoallergenic deodorizing systems.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Toilet and bathing rooms have protective containers for disposal of sharp needles.

H3_Sec_Title: General Toilet and Bathing Room Features
Standard_Text: Selected toilet and bathing rooms have a telephone or other emergency communication system.

H3_Sec_Title: Companion Care / Family Toilet and Bathing Rooms
Standard_Text: Companion care / family toilet and bathing rooms are identified by a sign with text and graphics that do not restrict use to a particular gender (e.g. "Toilet Room," "Family Toilet Room," "Companion Care Toilet Room," etc.).

H3_Sec_Title: Companion Care / Family Toilet and Bathing Rooms
Standard_Text: Companion care / family toilet and bathing rooms display a sign indicating the room is occupied when the door is locked, and indicating vacancy when unlocked.

H3_Sec_Title: Companion Care / Family Toilet and Bathing Rooms
Standard_Text: Companion care / family toilet and bathing rooms provided in addition to the required accessible toilet rooms have swing up-grab bars and transfer space on both sides of the toilet.

H3_Sec_Title: Companion Care / Family Toilet and Bathing Rooms
Standard_Text: Companion care / family toilet and bathing rooms have an auxiliary child seat with securement system.
Selected toilet compartments have a lavatory and mirror within the compartment.
Toilet compartments have a clear floor space on one side of every toilet.
Toilet compartments not designated as accessible are designed as ambulatory toilet compartments with grab bars.
Selected toilet compartments not designated as accessible have a clear floor space on both sides of the toilet and swing-up grab bars.
Toilet compartments are deep enough to accommodate luggage and parcels.
Storage is available within toilet compartments (e.g. hooks, shelves), or outside if securable.
Waste receptacles for disposal of single-use items are available within the toilet compartment.
Toilets are available on the premises with two differing seat heights, or at least one toilet has an adjustable seat height (without the use of after-market removable risers).
Toilets have touchless flush controls (automatic or non-automatic).
Toilets with touchless flush controls sense the minimum water volume necessary for flush.
Toilet flush controls are intuitive or labeled to indicate proper operation.
Toilets have a disposable protective barrier dispenser mounted forward of the toilet bowl, have an automated protective seat barrier, or are otherwise automatically sanitized after each use.
Urinals are positioned such that the user clear floor space does not obstruct the circulation space.
Urinals have modesty panels or walls on both sides, with sufficient width for a single wheelchair user.
Selected urinals have grab bars.
Urinals are positioned so that people outside the toilet room cannot see the urinals or their reflection when the door is open.
Urinals have touchless flush controls.
Urinals do not require flushing due to the use of a waterless fixture.
Lavatories and counters are adjustable in height or are available at more than one height.
Lavatory faucets are automatic or are operated following a common conceptual model.
Lavatory faucets give each user control over the temperature.
Lavatories have an adjacent storage space where items will not get wet.
Dispensers and hand drying equipment activate automatically.
Dispensers and hand drying equipment electronically alert staff when low on supply.
Dispensers and hand drying equipment have a side approach available.
Roll-in showers are available, and all others are transfer showers.
Shower and bathing areas have grab bars unobstructed by items hanging on hooks or towel rods.
Shower and bathing areas have adjustable height, hand-held shower spray units with controls and shelves available within the reach.
Selected shower and bathing areas have a private area enclosed by a door or curtain containing a dry changing area, seat, and towel hooks or rods within reach.
Goals: Body FitComfortWellnessCultural Appropriateness

Standard_Text: Shower and bathing areas are available for use by families or to allow assistance by opposite-gender companions.
Shower and bathing controls are reachable from outside the fixture.
Shower and bathing controls follow a common conceptual model.
Shower and bathing controls give each user control over the temperature.
Changing areas are available for use by families or to allow assistance by opposite-gender companions.
Changing areas are available in a private area with door or curtain.
Changing areas have seating.
Nursing rooms are separate from toilet rooms, contain a locking door, seat, changing table, electric outlet, and space for a stroller.
Nursing rooms have a refrigerator and/or sink.
Nursing rooms have companion seating.
Waiting areas do no not obstruct circulation spaces.
Waiting areas have seats.
Waiting areas with fixed or moveable queues are wide enough to allow passage of one wheeled mobility device and allow  a 180-degree turn wherever the queue changes direction.
Waiting areas with queues have adjustable boundaries that reduce travel distance when the queue is not full.
Outdoor waiting areas protect people from sun, wind, and/or inclement weather and/or have active heating or cooling mechanisms (e.g. radiant heat/cooling, heat lamps, fans, misters, etc.).
Waiting areas have a visual and audible system that clarifies the patrons already served and those still waiting to be served.
Waiting areas provide visual and audible information on remaining wait time.
Waiting areas with separate queues are differentiated by signs in multiple formats (e.g. symbols, print, large print, online, multiple languages, tactile, verbal)
Waiting areas have systems that reduce reliance on staff for services, such as automated kiosks, advance internet reservations, paging systems, etc.
Office spaces have furniture sized and arranged to allow wheeled mobility users to navigate through the entire space.
Office spaces are available in various capacities.
Selected office spaces have built-in and user-adjustable privacy controls (e.g. doors, sound proofing, blinds, room dividers, etc.).
Meeting rooms and classrooms have furniture sized and arranged to allow wheeled mobility users to navigate the entire space.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Meeting rooms and classrooms are available in various capacities.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Meeting rooms and classrooms are equipped with assistive listening systems.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Meeting rooms and classrooms are equipped with at least one display sized to be visible by every occupant.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Meeting rooms and classrooms have displays that are within reach and are operable by seated and standing people or have a remote control capable of controlling all functions of the display.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Meeting rooms and classrooms have wireless internet connections and/or wireless connection to audio/video system in addition to the internet.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Selected meeting rooms and classrooms have built-in and user-adjustable privacy controls (e.g. doors, sound proofing, blinds, room dividers, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 4 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 3 of 7

Standard_Text: Public assembly spaces have a presentation area that is physically accessible to all users.
Public assembly spaces have presentation equipment that is adjustable or moveable, and controls that are within reach.
Public assembly spaces have a presentation area that is visible from every seat and designed to ensure people in the back can see over the heads of people in front.
Public assembly spaces have selected spectator areas for wheeled mobility device users that can be accessed from at least two sides (e.g. back and side, back and front, etc.).
Public assembly spaces have adjustable spectator seating areas that accommodate various configurations.
Aisles serving general seating areas are not separated from those serving accessible seating areas.
Aisle edges are marked with a distinct color and/or texture.
Aisles in dark rooms are illuminated using a diffuser or reflective device such that bulbs are not directly visible by room occupants.
Aisles on a primary route have a tactile guide strips leading patrons to the nearest appropriate entrances and exits.
Food service areas have appliances, counters, tray slides, buffets, condiments, tableware, and accompaniment stations are all within reach and adjacent to a clear floor space.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Food service areas have tables arranged so wheeled mobility users can access them without obstructing the circulation space or disrupting other patrons.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Selected outdoor dining areas are adjacent to indoor dining areas.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Selected outdoor dining areas are on a hard surface (e.g. concrete, wood decking, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Selected outdoor dining areas have an active heating or cooling mechanism (e.g. radiant heat/cooling, heat lamps, fans, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Drive-through food service lines accommodate full-size vans.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Food service lines for take-out are separated from other food service lines, waiting, and/or dining areas.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 3 of 7      |      1 Credit: Implement 2 of 7

Standard_Text: Aisles are the width of two clear floor spaces.
Aisles have an intersecting aisle at both ends.
Aisles do not have displays or other obstructions that reduce the effective width of the aisle.
Aisles have signs that list aisle contents, located overhead and perpendicular to the cross-aisle.
Aisles have signs at each end that list aisle contents in multiple formats (e.g. , text, pictogram, Braille, audio, etc.).
Aisles near toilet rooms and transaction machines have extra space for people to temporarily store shopping carts outside of the circulation space.
Product displays have an adjacent clear floor space.
Product displays intended for customer interaction or retrieval are within reach or have a means of summoning staff assistance.
Product displays intended for customer interaction or retrieval have a moveable step available for reaching high items.
Product displays expose customers to all goods without requiring them to move items out of the way.
Product displays arrange products by category (e.g. by size, brand, style, etc.).
Pricing and product information is provided for all merchandise.
Pricing and product information is readable with a smartphone or store-provided scanner.
Pricing and product information dependent on product weight can be ascertained by the customer prior-to checkout using scales with label printers.
Sleeping rooms designated as accessible are available at every price point and are horizontally and vertically dispersed.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms are located where there is no more than one intersecting route between the room and nearest accessible elevator (or lobby, if on entrance level).
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms are arranged in zones that are visually differentiated by color, architectural features, or landmarks.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Selected sleeping rooms designated as accessible are available near elevators and/or amenities (such as pools, lounges, or vending areas).
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms designated as accessible have a wheelchair/scooter parking area outside of circulation space with an adjacent electrical outlet.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have a storage space large enough to store luggage outside of the circulation space.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms are available with a variety of different furniture layouts within each price point.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have moveable furniture.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have connectivity to electrical power at the bedside.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms allow remote control of room features such as entertainment system, lighting, thermostat, security system, etc.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have universal electrical plug adapters.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have user-controlled task lighting at the bedside and at any work station.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have lighting controls within reach of a person in bed.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms have a securable safe along an accessible route with accessible operating mechanisms that provide audio and visual feedback during securement.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms (or bathing rooms within) provide a hair dryer.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Sleeping rooms (or bathing rooms within) provide an adjustable mirror for detailed grooming tasks.
Instruction: 3 Credits: Implement 9 of 16      |      2 Credits: Implement 8 of 16      |      1 Credit: Implement 7 of 16

Standard_Text: Storage spaces are available or adjustable to be within reach (including drawers, shelves, clothing rods, etc.).
Storage spaces are illuminated.
Storage spaces illuminate automatically when the door is opened.
Storage spaces are securable.
Selected storage spaces are moveable.
At least 50% of washers and 50% of dryers are front loading and have controls within reach.
Laundry facilities have folding areas available at multiple heights or that are height-adjustable.
Laundry facilities have seating.
Play areas are enclosed.
Play areas have seating for parents and guardians within the enclosed area.
Play area surfaces are continuous.
Play areas have seating within covered shelters to provide shade from sun, wind, and/or inclement weather.
Play areas have trash receptacles.
Play areas have equipment for different age, development, and ability levels.
Goals: Body FitUnderstandingSocial IntegrationPersonalization

H2_Sec_Title: Pet and Service Animal Relief Areas
Standard_Text: Pet and service animal relief areas are provided and enclosed.

H2_Sec_Title: Pet and Service Animal Relief Areas
Standard_Text: Pet and service animal relief areas have a water trough or basin with a faucet that can replenish the supply without the need to touch the trough or basin.

H2_Sec_Title: Pet and Service Animal Relief Areas
Standard_Text: Pet and service animal relief areas have waste clean-up tools and disposal bin.

H2_Sec_Title: Pet and Service Animal Relief Areas
Standard_Text: Pet and service animal relief areas are staffed.
Exercise spaces have cardiovascular and physical strength equipment with a clear floor space on at least one side of at least one type of each equipment.
Fitness classrooms and/or group workout rooms are provided (e.g. dance, yoga, meditation, etc.).
Exercise spaces have cleaning equipment and towels within reach.
Exercise spaces have locker rooms, shower/bathing rooms, and toilet rooms adjacent to the space.
Seats have a variety of feature and height options.
Seats are available with armrests.
Seats are available with open space underneath.
Seats are available with backrests.
Seats in secure areas are moveable, and have wheels and/or are lightweight.
Seats at work stations have thoracic and lumbar support features.
Seats for outdoor use are adjacent to a circulation space.
Seats for outdoor use are available in both shaded and unshaded areas, and are protected against splashing from bicycle and vehicular traffic.
Seats for outdoor use are located in a shelter from sun, wind, and/or inclement weather.
Tables are available at two or more heights.
Tables in secure areas are moveable, and have wheels and/or are lightweight.
The majority of surfaces and displays do not cause reflections and glare.
Furniture and solid surfaces, floors, and walls, can be cleaned with water, ozone, and/or non-toxic chemicals.
Furniture and solid surfaces are made of low-emitting materials.
Sales and service counters have sufficient clear floor space and/or knee and toe clearance at every desk/station.
Sales and service counters have a sufficient number of stations to satisfy patron needs during periods of peak demand.
Sales and service counters have low countertops or multiple levels at every desk/station.
Selected sales and service counters have an inductive loop system or other assistive communication system (e.g. text communication system).
Sales and service counters have a nearby kiosk available for self-assistance (e.g. product availability and location, frequently asked questions, etc.).
Work stations have space underneath for knees and toes.
Work stations have adjustable height chairs.
Work stations have adjustable height work surfaces and/or can be configured for sitting or standing work upon request.
Work stations have user-controlled task lighting.
Work stations with computers have adjustable keyboard trays.
Work stations with computers have a flat work space on the left and right side of computer station.
Work stations with computers have a wire management system.
Work stations for standing work are designed to avoid unnecessary bending, lifting, or twisting.
Work stations are available for group work, including nontraditional  and alternative working styles (e.g. lounge, game rooms, etc.).
Work stations share a central hub containing shared supplies and resources (e.g. printers, copiers, office supplies, etc.).
Work stations in factory settings have equipment to assist in moving heavy loads.
Waste receptacles either have no door, a motion-activated door, or an attached door that does not provide resistance (e.g. is not spring-loaded).
Waste receptacles for recyclable materials are located next to selected garbage receptacles and have a distinct visual appearance, including differentiating color, pictogram, and text.

Waste receptacles are sized to be commensurate with demand and maintenance schedule, and are located at all entrances/exits to spaces with different primary functions and at all intersecting circulation spaces.
Drinking water fountains have two or more available spout heights at every location.
Drinking water fountains have an integrated bottle filling station or are adjacent to a means of filling water bottles with one hand (e.g. water cooler).
Selected drinking water dispensers offer cold and hot water options.
Lockers are available at various heights, with hooks and shelves at various heights.
Lockers have electronic securement systems with clear instructions.
Transaction machines have a centered clear floor space for forward approach with knee and toe clearances, or a clear floor space for a parallel approach.
Transaction machines have two overlapping clear floor spaces, one with the machine centerline aligned with the right shoulder, and the other aligned with the left shoulder.
Transaction machines have an adjacent shelf for resting personal belongings within reach.
Transaction machines have sufficient space for a waiting queue.
Transaction machines have instructions, customer service staff in close proximity, or link to contact customer support visible at all times.
Transaction machines have all controls, functions, and displays reachable and viewable from both seated and standing positions.

Transaction machines provide at least 5 of the following features:1) Information in more than one format (e.g. print, symbol, multiple languages, tactile, verbal)2) Audio component with volume control and headphone jack3) Adjustable text size and contrast4) "Cancel" option to undo incorrect input and go back to a previous step5) Visual and audible feedback on all actions6) Functions arranged and/or color-coded to correspond with the order of use7) More than one form of payment accepted, including cash, check, money order, credit card, smart card, online payment services, and smartphone8) Eject tray or other dispenser allowing secure retrieval of product with one hand9) Security features such as a mirror or display to allow any user to see behind them, shielded keypad, video surveillance, emergency call function, and/or sufficient lighting
Telephones have a visual communication option (e.g. video screen, text messaging).
Telephones have a hands free option (e.g. speakerphone, wireless headset).
Computer screens are adjustable in height or view angle.
Computers have wireless connectivity to technology peripherals.
Equipment and emergency controls are visible and located within reach.
Selected equipment is moveable and adjustable to fit different users.
Selected equipment on platforms can be accessed via elevator, lift, or ramp.
Vegetation provides shady areas on exterior pedestrian circulation spaces and at seating areas.
Vegetation is low-pollen, not poisonous, and devoid of thorns or other abrasive elements.
Vegetation that routinely drops foliage, needles, flowers, nuts, fruit, or similar material is located such that the branches are not directly above a circulation space.
Customer service is trained and equipped to provide people with assistance, including people with disabilities.
Goals: Body FitAwarenessUnderstandingSocial IntegrationWellness

Standard_Text: Customer service is trained and equipped to provide assistive technology (e.g. assistive listening devices) and/or setup real-time captioning services.
Customer service is equipped to reference past preferences provided by the customer.
Customer service has a text telephone (TTY) access line or online text chat service.

Customer service telephone lines have 3 of the following features:1) Information on waiting time2) Language option3) Live operator option4) On-hold music or announcements5) Touch-tone keypad entered information is not collected again by operator
Purchasing services accept more than one form of payment (e.g. cash, check, money order, credit card, online payment, smartphone).
Purchasing services include secure transmission of customer and payment data.
Purchasing services allow customer pick-up at a facility with a covered area.
Purchasing services notify the customer when an order is ready for pick-up.
Purchasing services provide a home delivery option.
Purchasing services assist in assembling or installing items purchased.
Purchasing services provide a personal shopper service.
Purchasing services include ordering over the telephone or online with real-time order status updates.
Purchasing services include ordering, tracking, and paying via smartphone or tablet application.
Purchasing services explain the entire ordering and delivery process prior to finalizing the order.
Child Care services are equipped to provide assistance to children and adults with disabilities.
Goals: Body FitAwarenessUnderstandingSocial IntegrationWellness

Standard_Text: Child Care services have security measures such as fences, automatically locking doors, and policies and procedures governing to whom children may be released.
Child Care services have play equipment for different ages and ability levels.
Child Care services have staff supervisors on site or available by telephone.
Food is nutritious and replenished frequently in vending machines.
Food selection accommodates people with various dietary restrictions and preferences.
Food source is on-site garden or local farms and businesses.
Food orders can be placed via telephone, text message, and/or online service with immediate confirmation.
Menus provide information in multiple formats (e.g. print, large print, online, multiple languages, tactile, verbal)
Menus and/or food products provide nutrition information for all offerings (e.g. calories, trans fat, etc.).
Menus and/or food products identify items for people with dietary restrictions with a special symbol (e.g. for peanut-free, low-calorie, vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, etc.).
Menus reiterate any information typically posted on handwritten signs, posters, blackboards, etc. (e.g. daily/weekly specials, beverage options, side dishes, etc.)
Menus are available online.
On-site services include a parking shuttle service or a valet service.
On-site services include a bicycle valet service and/or valet for other forms of alternative transportation.
On-site services include medical service for treatment of illness or injury, and consultation.
On-site services include pharmacy service.
On-site services include child care service.
On-site services include concierge service.
On-site services include on-site banking and/or automatic teller machines.
On-site services include on-site postal service (e.g. staffed kiosk, drop boxes, automated postage and mailing machines, etc.)
On-site services include on-site laundry, dry cleaning, and/or alterations service.
On-site services include a convenience store.
On-site services include automobile repair, maintenance, and/or washing and detailing service.
On-site services include salon and grooming service (e.g. beauty, hair, spa, etc.)
Goals: Cultural AppropriatenessSocial IntegrationWellnessComfort

Standard_Text: On-site services include shuttle service to public transit stops and off-site services (e.g. bank, restaurants, post office, etc.).
Goals: Body FitCultural AppropriatenessComfortWellness

Standard_Text: Websites and smartphone applications comply with W3C Standards.

Websites and smartphone applications have 6 of the following features:1) information in multiple languages2) plain text option3) feedback on successful completion of tasks (in both visual or audible modes)4) ability to cancel actions and go back to a previous step at any time5) intuitive navigation structure6) intuitive login process7) accessible alternative to any visual challenge-response test (e.g. CAPTCHA)8) access to search and site map from every page9) information on current and past locations in the navigation structure10) help pages that provide immediate guidance or answers to frequently asked questions

Websites and smartphone applications have 2 of the following features:1) price comparisons of comparable products2) customer feedback mechanisms (e.g. reviews of products and services, surveys, etc.)3) reservation, appointment scheduling, and/or purchasing options4) manuals and/or step-by-step guides for  product operation and maintenance, procedures for obtaining service, and warranty information5) information for navigating the physical site, including entrance/exit locations, parking locations, accessible parking, loading areas, accessible routes, etc. in an accessible format
Workplace policies include various career pathways to senior-level positions.
Workplace policies include consulting, training, and regularly evaluating employee work spaces for comfort and ergonomics, and providing adaptive furniture and equipment when necessary.
Workplace policies include incentives for employees to participate in health and wellness programs (e.g. exercise, weight loss challenges, etc.)
Workplace policies include opportunities for consulting with mental health professionals (e.g., managing work-life balance,  stress management, etc.).
Workplace policies include opportunities to join support groups (e.g. smoking cessation, weight loss, addiction, coping, family crisis, etc.).
Workplace policies ensure all employees can participate in all work events and gatherings.
Workplace policies include incentives for alternative transportation users (e.g. bicycle, public transportation, ride sharing service).
Workplace policies include programs for professional and career development.
Facility management policies include a continuous quality control program for facility grounds, spaces, and amenities.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure routine maintenance of HVAC system, including replacement of air filters.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies involve staff training on responsibilities for maintaining an inclusive environment (e.g. ensuring appropriately sized and placed furniture).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies involve staff training on all maintenance procedures and updates.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies include a rapid response team for emergency maintenance issues.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure staff scheduling is commensurate with demand.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies provide for preventative maintenance and testing.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure walking surfaces are kept dry.

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure routine cleaning and disinfecting of frequently touched surfaces (e.g. bathrooms, food preparation areas, door handles, light switches, railings, etc.).
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies require use of cleaners and supplies that do not have chemicals known to be toxic, or otherwise potentially hazardous to one's health.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies include a designated fragrance free zone.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure all transit routes, circulation spaces, and entrances are cleared of snow or debris in a timely manner.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure directions to alternative routes are available whenever access is temporarily restricted.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure vegetation is cared for as part of a regular maintenance schedule.
Instruction: 2 Credits: Implement 8 of 18      |      1 Credit: Implement 6 of 18

Standard_Text: Facility management policies ensure waste receptacles are emptied regularly.

Standard_Text: Facility management policies include a waste reduction program (e.g. incentives for staff and visitors).

Standard_Text: Facility management policies include comprehensive recycling (e.g. incentives for staff and visitors).

Standard_Text: Facility management policies include on-site composting of biodegradable waste.

Standard_Text: Public safety policies include a preparedness plan and training program available in visual and tactile and/or audible format to facilitate the immediate evacuation of all building occupants, including people who need assistance.
Public safety policies include procedures and equipment that address the needs of people with communication impairments during emergencies.
Public safety policies include emergency systems that automatically activate visual and verbal evacuation prompts and instructions.
Public safety policies include ensuring every building has least one accessible automated external defibrillator (AED) and signs directing people to its location.
Public safety policies include a training program for certifying staff in emergency assistance, including AED use, with annual refresher courses.
Public safety policies include conspicuous posting of local emergency telephone numbers unless number is uniform nationally (e.g. 9-1-1, or 9-9-9).
Public safety policies include procedures establishing a person in charge and/or chain of command in emergency situations.
Public safety policies include a training program on public safety policies and issues, with training materials available in visual and tactile and/or audible format.
Public safety policies include a public address system.
Public safety policies include a text message, email, and/or telephone emergency alert system.
Public safety policies include a staffed security station and/or roving patrols.
Public safety policies include a video surveillance system that covers strategic locations (e.g. stairways, transit shelters, etc.).
Public safety policies include strategically placed two-way emergency communication devices.
Public safety policies include provisions permitting employees to work from home during dangerous, inclement weather.
Public safety policies include instituting and designating food allergen-free environments.
